dry is now much better than at any

OUR SCHOOLS,
School facilities in East Nashville
for Negroes are whotly insufficient
Meigs School is inadequate to care

Negro children
who are entitled to school privileges
Now is the time for our public-spiri-
ited citizens to call the attention of
for the hundreds of

the Board of Education to this mat-|
ter. How can the authorities know
we desire betterment in our ‘schools
if we don't ask? Perhaps all are

satisfied with the conditions as they}
exist. If you wish better educational
advantages for your children, let the
fact Maybe, some of our
ministers will stop a picnic or a rally |
long enough to call the attention of |
be known.

schools, Nashville needs more schools
for her Negro. children. Nashville

MORNING SONG TO ARTEMIS.

Artemis,
O, huntress, wake!
Leave thy car; descend to earth;
Night today has given birth.
Come, awake, for ‘tis the morn;
Hear the winding of the horn.
Over hill and vale today,
Where sunshine and shadow play,
There with quiver and with bow,
Chase the timid hart and roe.
Artemis, :
O, huntress, wake! ‘

Morn is smiling o’er the hill,
And the deer drink at the rill
Come, awake, and on the breeze
Let us wake the woods with glees
Over hill and vale today,

We with thee will wanton stray.
There with quiver and with bow,
Chase the timid hart and roe.
Artemis,
wake!
When Anollo fiercely beams
We shall bathe with thee in streams,
Or within the limped pool,
In the forest shade so cool,
Over field and over mead,
Where the wild deer gently feed,
There with quiver and with bow

and roe
—Frankie C. DeBerry.

week. Miss Maud Allen has return-)

pained by little Syrillar B, Alten.

The Thirtieth Session of the Mis-
|sionary Baptist State Convention of
lthe State of Tennessee of the unin-
lcorporated Baptists of America met
|with the Mt. Zion Baptist Church at

lery train, North and South Bound
brought a host of Sunday School and
B. Y. P. U. Workers to what pro-
lmises to be the best session of this

Church.

WAVERLY.

‘Friday evening last, closed a suc-
cessful term of Institute work of
which Prof. M. C. Jones and P. P.
Whitson were instructors. Those in
attendance were Misses Mattia L.
Barr, F. A. Jones, Bertha McWilliams,
Francis Phiffer, Elsie Dronnie, Inez
Lucas, Flora Jones, Hallie Beard, Al-
lie Walker, Ada Whitson. The closing!
program was very interesting ax |\Well|
as enjoyable. The debate iwas_ well
taken in by a very appreciative audi-
ence, Subject, “Resolved, that a \Vom-
an Should not Vote.” The judges de-
cided in favor of the negative, Rev.
H. BE. Rye preached two able sermons
Sunday. Hon. W. B. Bowman, State
Attorney and Mr. C. W. Cowens de-
| livered an interesting address at 3 o’-

clock in interest of the Red Cross
Movement. Born to Mr. and Mrs.
Houston Mayes, a fine boy. Mrs. Ad-
die Oneida Walker, who has’ been
quite ill is now convalescing. Little
Misses Jewel and Walter Cortez Col:
lier of St. Louis, Mo., is spending the
summer with their grand mother, Mrs.
